title: Immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons and microplastics alone or in combination to a bivalve species: synergic impacts and potential toxication mechanisms
abstract: Both the frequent occurrence of accidental petroleum spills and the ubiquitous presence of microplastics (MPs) in the sea may pose severe threats to marine species. However, the immunotoxic impacts of these two types of pollutants and the underlying toxication mechanisms still remain largely unknown in sessile filter-feeding bivalve mollusks. Therefore, the impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination on the total count, cell type composition, and phagocytic activity of hemocytes were investigated in the blood clam, Tegillarca granosa. In addition, the intracellular ROS content, cell viability, degree of DNA damage, and expression levels of genes from immune-, apoptosis-, and immunotoxicity-related pathways were analyzed to reveal the potential toxication mechanisms. The results demonstrated that exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination at environmentally realistic concentrations could exert significant immunotoxic impacts on the blood clam, which may be caused by alterations in a series of physiological and molecular processes. In addition, the immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons could be significantly aggravated by the copresence of MPs, which suggests that coexposure to these two pollutants deserves closer attention.

abstract.text: Both the frequent occurrence of accidental petroleum spills and the ubiquitous presence of microplastics (MPs) in the sea may pose severe threats to marine species. However, the immunotoxic impacts of these two types of pollutants and the underlying toxication mechanisms still remain largely unknown in sessile filter-feeding bivalve mollusks. Therefore, the impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination on the total count, cell type composition, and phagocytic activity of hemocytes were investigated in the blood clam, Tegillarca granosa. In addition, the intracellular ROS content, cell viability, degree of DNA damage, and expression levels of genes from immune-, apoptosis-, and immunotoxicity-related pathways were analyzed to reveal the potential toxication mechanisms. The results demonstrated that exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination at environmentally realistic concentrations could exert significant immunotoxic impacts on the blood clam, which may be caused by alterations in a series of physiological and molecular processes. In addition, the immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons could be significantly aggravated by the copresence of MPs, which suggests that coexposure to these two pollutants deserves closer attention.

body_text.text: Petroleum pollution of marine environments caused by the accidental release of petroleum from tankers, drilling rigs, and wells and the leakage of refined petroleum products and their byproducts frequently occurs, thus posing a great threat to marine organisms and ecosystems (Almeda et al., 2013; Lee et al., 2015) . The unintentional discharge of approximately 4.63 million tons of petroleum into the ocean has been estimated from transportation every year, which has led to great public concern over its deleterious ecological impacts (Carpenter, 2019) . For example, a series of adverse physiological impacts and massive mortality of various marine species have been recorded for some major oil spill accidents, such as the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989 and the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in 2010, in which over 42,000 tons and approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil were released into the Prudhoe Bay and Gulf of Mexico, respectively (Zhang et al., 2019) .

Crude oil is a unique combination of several thousand of compounds that mainly include hydrocarbons such as saturates, olefins, and aromatics, along with a small fraction of nonhydrocarbon compounds such as sulfur and some trace metals (Beens and Brinkman, 2000; Colvin et al., 2020) . Once entering the ocean, the composition of crude oil can be altered through a series of physical, chemical, and biological reactions, such as evaporation, dissolution, biodegradation, photolysis, and sedimentation (NRC, 2003) . Generally, the water accommodated fraction (WAF) of petroleum, which is an aqueous fraction containing a dissolved suspended fraction of petroleum, plays an important role in the toxicity of petroleum products (OECD, 2018) . For instance, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), one of the most carcinogenic, teratogenic, and mutagenic components of WAF, have been demonstrated to be highly immunotoxic to various aquatic species and humans (Omar-Ali et al., 2015) . According to the reports, the concentration of total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPHs) in the polluted seawater varies dramatically in a spatially and temporally dependent manner. For example, an average μg/L of TPHs was found for the Hebei Spirit oil spill in 2007, and this value drastically decreased to approximately 31.0 μg/L one month later (Kim et al., 2013) . Similarly, the concentration of TPH varied dramatically from 0 to 7,270,000 μg/L at the Gulf Science Base at different distances to the incidence point after the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, with 95% of the samples presenting a TPH concentration of less than 250 μg/L (Wade et al., 2016) .

For more than 50 years, the continuous growth of the global production and consumption of plastics (over 300 million tons every year) has led to a new environmental problem: plastic pollution (Jambeck et al., 2015; Faggio et al., 2018; Guzzetti et al., 2018; Strungaru et al., 2018; Alimba et al., 2019) . A significant proportion of plastic waste has a diameter less than mm and is termed microplastics (MPs), which are mainly derived from microbeads discharged from cosmetics and suggest that approximately 15 to 51 trillion pieces of MPs are in the ocean, which poses a severe threat to various marine organisms (van Sebille et al., 2015) .

Due to the small size of MPs, these particles can be easily ingested by many marine animals and could even enter the circulatory system by passing through the intestine cavity (Browne et al., 2008; Wright et al., 2013; Pagano et al., 2019; Savoca et al., 2019a,b) , resulting in a series of adverse impacts such as retarded growth (Besseling et al., 2014) , arrested embryonic development (Sussarellu et al., 2016) , and hampered immune responses (Tang et al., 2020) . In addition, because of their large surface-to-volume ratios and hydrophobic properties, MPs can act as vectors that facilitate the internalization of other pollutants, such as heavy metals, PAHs, and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) (Rochman et al., 2013a; Bakir et al., 2014a; Brennecke et al., 2016; Massos and Turner, 2017) . For instance, the amount of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) that can be adsorbed on the surface of MPs could reach to approximately 10 6 times higher than that in the surrounding seawater (Lohmann, 2017) . Although a growing number of studies suggest that coexposure between MPs and other pollutants, such as fluoranthene, polybrominated diphenyls, 17b-estradiol, sertraline, and benzo[a]pyrene, may result in aggravated toxicity to aquatic animals (Rochman et al., 2013; Paul-Pont et al., 2016; Rainieri et al., 2018; Shi et al., 2020; Tang et al., 2020) , to the best of our knowledge, the combined toxic impacts of petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs still remain poorly understood in marine bivalve invertebrates.

Invertebrates are major animal species that play crucial roles in marine ecosystems such as providing habitats (i.e., coral reefs and mussel beds) and acting as prey or predators for other organisms . Among these invertebrates, sessile bivalves may be more susceptible to pollutants such as MPs and petroleum hydrocarbons due to their limited locomotory capacity and filter-feeding lifestyle (Newell et al., 2005; Jasperse et al., 2018; Shi et al., 2019) . Since a robust immune response is essential for the health and survival of marine bivalves, any disruption in immunity may pose a severe threat to these species (Matozzo et al., 2012; Liu et al., 2016; Guan et al., 2018; Zha et al., 2019a) . However, the immune system of bivalve mollusks might be one of the main targets for both petroleum components and MPs (Wootton et al., 2003; von Moos et al., 2012; Canesi et al., 2015; Omar-Ali et al., 2015; Tang et al., 2020) , thus highlighting the need to identify the synergetic immunotoxic impacts of these two types of pollutants in bivalve species.

Without antigen-antibody-mediated immune responses, bivalves mainly rely on the phagocytosis of hemocytes to fight against pathogen invasion (Liu et al., 2016; Matozzo et al., 2016; Burgos-Aceves et al., 2018a,b; Freitas et al., 2019) . It has been suggested that many pollutants exert immunotoxic impacts on bivalves by inducing 6 intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS), causing DNA damage, hampering cell viability, altering the apoptosis process, and disrupting immune-related molecular signaling pathways (Guan et al., 2019; Zha et al., 2019a; Tang et al., 2020) . Though a few case studies have been performed, the physiological and molecular mechanisms underlying the immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs remain poorly understood. In addition, pollutants containing aromatic compounds may exert immunotoxic impacts on organisms by activating the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) and aryl hydrocarbon receptor nuclear translocator (ARNT) (Ziv-Gal et al., 2013; Kim et al., 2015; Hong et al., 2016; Van den Eede et al., 2016; Schönlau et al., 2019) . Since petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs often contain aromatic components (i.e., aryl phosphate, one of typical flame retardants used in plastic production), AHR and ARNT may represent common targets for these two types of pollutants through which they exert immunotoxicity (Pilcher et al., 2014; Schönlau et al., 2019) . However, this speculation still awaits verification with empirical data.

The blood clam, T. granosa, is a typical sessile filter-feeding marine bivalve species, which is widely distributed along coastal areas of the Indo-Pacific region (Shao et al., 2016; . Though this species has been used to investigate the ecotoxicological impacts of various pollutants (Su et al., 2017; Shi et al., 2018a; Zha et al., 2019b) , to the best of our knowledge, the immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons and underlying toxication mechanisms still remain unknown in blood clam, especially in the copresence of MPs. Therefore, using one major type of MPs, namely, polystyrene (PS) MPs, and a standard mix of petroleum hydrocarbons (standard mix for GB252-2000, National Standard of China), the immunotoxic impacts of petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination on blood clam were investigated in the present study. In addition, to reveal the underlying toxication mechanisms, the intracellular ROS content, cell viability and degree of DNA damage of hemocytes in blood clams after 14 days of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination were analyzed. Furthermore, the expression levels of genes from the immune-related NFκB signaling pathway, the AHR-immunotoxicity pathway, and the apoptosis pathway upon petroleum hydrocarbons and/or MP exposure were assessed.

Adult blood calms (shell height of 23.01 ± 1.93 mm) were collected in June 2019 from Yueqing Bay, Zhejiang, China (28°280' N and 121°110' E), and immediately transported to the Zhejiang Mariculture Research Institute. Subsequently, the clams were acclimated in a 1000-L plastic tank filled with 800 L of sand-filtered 24-h aerated seawater (temperature 22.5 ± 0.8 °C, pH 8.07 ± 0.06, salinity 20.7 ± 0.8‰).

Blood clams were acclimated for two weeks before the commencement of the experiments, during which time the clams were fed the microalga Tetraselmis chuii at the satiation feed rate twice a day and the seawater was replaced with fresh sand-filtered seawater daily.

PS MPs are among the most abundant MPs in the marine environment (Claessens et al., 2011; Enders et al., 2015; Alimi et al., 2018; Guo and Wang, 2019) and thus were chosen as a representative of MPs in this study. According to previous studies, compared to their counterparts with smaller sizes, MPs larger than 20 μm have limited ability to enter the circulatory system of bivalve species and are less efficient to facilitate the internalization of other pollutants due to a relative smaller surface-to-volume ratio (Browne et al., 2008; Van Cauwenberghe and Janssen, 2014; Tang et al., 2020) . In this circumstance, immunotoxicity and synergic effects with other pollutants, if any, of MPs larger than 20 µm have significant implications for their smaller sized counterparts. Therefore, commercial PS MPs at the nominal size of 30 μm were purchased from the Regal Nano-plastic Engineering Research Institute (Jiangsu, China) and were used in the present study after size verification via a microscope (micrograph and physicochemical properties of the PS MPs are provided in Figure S1 and Table S1, respectively). The standard mix of petroleum hydrocarbons (CDAA-GBW(E)080913, standard mix for GB252-2000, National Standard of China) was purchased from ANPEL Laboratory Technologies Inc. (Shanghai).

According to the previous reports mentioned above (Kim et al., 2013; Wade et al., 2016) , 50 and 100 μg/L were adopted as the exposure concentrations for petroleum hydrocarbons in this study to simulate petroleum spill pollution scenarios. In addition, a dose of 0.26 mg/L PS MPs was chosen to mimic an environmentally realistic level of MP pollution (Sussarellu et al., 2016; Barboza et al., 2018) . In total, six experimental groups were set up in triplicate in this study, namely, (1) a control without petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs, (2) an MP exposure group containing 0.26 mg/L PS MPs, (3) two petroleum hydrocarbon exposure groups exposed to 50 or 100 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons, and (4) two coexposure groups treated with 0.26 mg/L MPs along with 50 or 100 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons. For simplicity, the abbreviations PL and PH were used post hoc to indicate exposure to the low and high doses of petroleum hydrocarbons, respectively.
body_text.section: Exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination

body_text.text: After 14 days of acclimation, 540 clams were randomly selected and assigned into 18 experimental tanks (6 experimental groups × replicates, 30 individuals/replicates) filled with 30 L of sand-filtered seawater containing corresponding doses of petroleum hydrocarbons and/or MPs. The exposure lasted for 14 days, during which the clams were fed the microalgae T. chuii twice a day and the seawater was replaced daily with desired concentrations of petroleum hydrocarbons and/or MPs. The concentration of petroleum hydrocarbons in each experimental trial was determined following the method described by Kim et al (2013) with Millipore deionized water adopted as blank control. According to measurement, the background concentration of petroleum hydrocarbons was found to be under the detection limit of 0.52 µg/L (Table S2 ). In addition, seawater was sampled from each experimental trial for the first three days of exposure to verify the consistency of petroleum hydrocarbons working concentration and no significant daily difference was detected (Table S3 ).
body_text.section: Exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination

body_text.text: The total hemocyte count (THC) and hemocyte cell type composition were determined following the methods of Shi et al. (2018b) and Zha et al. (2019a) . In brief, six individuals were randomly selected from each experimental group (n = 6) after 14 days of the corresponding treatment. A volume of 100 μL of hemolymph was extracted individually from the blood clam cavity using a 2-mL syringe and subsequently mixed with 800 μL of phosphate buffered saline (PBS, pH at 7.4) in a 1.5-mL centrifuge tube. After fixation with 100 μL of 2.5% glutaraldehyde, a wet mount was prepared with the hemocyte sample, and the THC was subsequently determined using a Neubauer's hemocytometer (XB-K-25, Anxin Optical Instrument) under a Nikon Eclipse E600 microscope at a magnification of 400×.
body_text.section: Determination of the total count and cell type composition of hemocytes 10

body_text.text: Following the methods of Tang et al. (2020) and Liu et al. (2016) , the cell type composition was estimated based on hemocytes collected from six clams (n = 6) from each experimental group. Briefly, after mixing 700 μL of hemolymph extracted from one clam with 300 μL of glutaraldehyde (2.5%), the mixture was centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 4 min. Blood smears were then prepared with μL of blood precipitate followed by staining with Wright's stain (G1020, Solarbio, China). According to Liu et al. (2016) , the percentages of red granulocytes, basophil granulocytes, and hyalinocytes were subsequently determined microscopically (Nikon Eclipse E600 microscope) at the magnification of 400× using the stained blood smear. More than 100 hemocytes were scored for each sample in this study to ensure data accuracy.
body_text.section: Determination of the total count and cell type composition of hemocytes 10

body_text.text: After 14 days of exposure, six clams (n = 6) were randomly selected from each experimental group and used for the phagocytosis assay following the methods described by Shi et al. (2017) and Su et al. (2018) . A volume of 100 μL of hemolymph extracted as described above was mixed with 100 μL of precooled Alsever's solution (R1016, Solarbio, China) in a 1.5-mL centrifuge tube. After microscopic determination of the hemocyte concentration, a previously prepared yeast suspension was added to the mixture at a yeast-to-hemocyte ratio of 10:1 followed by incubation at 25 °C for 30 min. The yeast suspension was prepared prior to use by dissolving mg of yeast powder (Instant dry yeast, Angel Yeast, China) in 1 mL of 0.1 M PBS.

After fixation with 100 μL of glutaraldehyde (2.5%), stained blood smears were made as described above, and the phagocytic rate of hemocytes was subsequently determined microscopically at the magnification of 400×. To ensure data accuracy, more than 200 hemocytes were scored for each sample in this assay.

Hemocytes collected from six clams (n = 6) out of each experimental group were used to measure the intracellular ROS content using a commercial 2',7'-dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) ROS kit (Beyotime Biotechnology, China) according to the manufacturer's protocol. In brief, hemocytes were incubated in PBS containing 10 μM DCFH-DA at 20 °C in the dark for 45 min.
body_text.section: Measurement of the intracellular ROS content

body_text.text: After three rounds of PBS washing, blood smears were prepared as mentioned above.
body_text.section: Measurement of the intracellular ROS content

body_text.text: Fluorescent images of the stained hemocyte samples were captured with a Nikon Eclipse E600 fluorescence microscope at the excitation and emission wavelengths of 520 and 590 nm, respectively. Following the methods of Guo et al. (2017) and Zha et al (2019a) , the images were analyzed with Image-Pro Plus 6.0 (Rockville, MD, USA), and the intracellular ROS content indicated by the specific fluorescent intensity was estimated using the following equation: fluorescent intensity = the total optical density of the stained hemocytes area / the stained area of hemocytes.
body_text.section: Measurement of the intracellular ROS content

body_text.text: After 14 days of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination, hemocytes collected from six clams (n = 6) out of each experimental group, and the cell viability was determined using a commercial MTT cell proliferation and cytotoxicity assay kit (Beyotime Biotechnology, China) following the methods of Zha et al. (2019a) . Briefly, 100 μL of hemocytes extracted from each clam was mixed with 10 μL of 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) solution (5 mg/mL) in a 96-well plate followed by incubation at °C in the dark for 4 h. After adding 100 μL of formazan solvent to each sample, the mixture was incubated at 37 °C in the dark until the complete dissolution of the formazan crystal. The absorbance value of each sample at the wavelength of 570 nm was determined with a microplate reader (Multiskan GO, Thermo, USA), and the relative cell viability was subsequently calculated by comparing the absorbance value obtained against that of the control.

In the present study, the degree of DNA damage of hemocytes was evaluated following the method described by Gong et al. (2018) and Zha et al. (2019b) using an OxiSelect TM comet assay kit (Cell Biolabs, San Diego, CA, USA). After the 14-day corresponding treatment, hemocytes were collected from three clams (n = 3) out of each experimental group. After mixing 7 μL of the hemocyte sample with 60 μL of 0.5% preheated low-melting-point agarose, the mixture was transferred onto a CometSlide TM and then incubated at 4 °C in the dark for 15 min. The solidified sample was then sequentially incubated with precooled lysis buffer (14.6 g NaCl, 20 ml EDTA, 10 ml of lysis solution) and alkaline buffer (provided) at 4 °C in the dark for 50 min and 30 min, respectively. Electrophoresis was subsequently conducted at 30 V for 12 min followed by two rounds (5 min each) of washing with distilled water and dehydration with 99% ethanol. After staining with Vista Green DNA dye for 15 min, fluorescent images were captured with a Nikon Eclipse E600 fluorescence microscope at excitation and emission wavelengths of and 590 nm, respectively.
body_text.section: Evaluation of the degree of DNA damage

body_text.text: The degree of DNA damage of each hemocyte sample was subsequently analyzed with Photoshop CS6 following the method of Gong et al. (2018) . To ensure data accuracy, at least 100 randomly selected cells were analyzed for each sample.
body_text.section: Evaluation of the degree of DNA damage

body_text.text: After the two-week corresponding treatment, six clams (n = 6) were randomly selected from each experimental group and dissected on ice. The gill tissue, where hemocytes are often concentrated (Guan et al., 2018) , was carefully peeled off and used for the gene expression analysis. Total RNA was extracted from the gill tissue of each individual using the EASYspin RNA extraction kit (RN2802, Aidlab). Gel electrophoresis and a NanoDrop 1000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific) were then employed to verify the quality and concentration of RNA, respectively. High-quality total RNA was subsequently used to synthesize the first-strand cDNA template with the PrimeScript RT Reagent Kit (TaKaRa, RR037A). Real-time PCR was conducted with a CFX96 Real-Time System (Bio-Rad, USA) using the following amplification cycles: denaturation at 95 °C for 5 min, 39 amplification cycles at 95 °C for 20 s, 61 °C for 20 s, and 72 °C for 20 s. The reliability of the qPCR products and the relative expression levels of the six tested genes were determined via melting curve analysis and the 2 −ΔΔCT method, respectively (Soares et al., 2013; Rao et al., 2013) . In total, the expression levels of six genes, namely, nuclear factor kappa B subunit 1 (NFκB1) and TAK1-binding protein 2 (TAB2) from the immune-related NFκB signaling pathway, aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) and aryl hydrocarbon receptor nuclear translocator (ARNT) from the AHR-immunotoxicity pathway, and

Caspase-3 and Bcl-2-associated X (BAX) from the apoptosis pathway, were analyzed in this study. 18S rRNA was adopted as an internal reference to calculate the relative expression level of the genes examined. All primers used in this study were synthesized by TsingKe Biotech (Hangzhou, China) and are listed in Table 1 .

One-way ANOVAs followed by Tukey's post hoc tests were performed to reveal the impacts of petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination on the THC, cell type composition, phagocytic activity, cell viability, intracellular ROS content, and degree of DNA damage of hemocytes. For all analyses, the homogeneity of variance and data normality were verified using Levene's and Shapiro-Wilk's tests, respectively (McDonald, 2014) . In cases where these assumptions were not satisfied by the raw data, arcsine square root transformation was performed before the analysis to fulfill the pre-assumption of ANOVA (Brosnan et al., 2011) . The gene expression levels were compared via Duncan multiple range tests. All the analyses were performed using the Origin-Pro 8 software package, and a p-value less than 0.05 was accepted as significant.

Compared to that in the control, the THC and cell type composition of hemocytes were significantly altered upon exposing blood clams to petroleum hydrocarbons and/or MPs (Table 2) . Treatment with both petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination led to a significant decline in the THC (Table 2 , F5,36 = 46.23, p = 3.32E-13). In addition, clams exposed to 100 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons had a significantly lower THC than those treated with 50 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons, suggesting that the toxic impact of petroleum hydrocarbons on the THC may occur in a dose-dependent manner although which still awaits further verification. Furthermore, exposure to 100 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons with the presence of MPs resulted in a significantly smaller THC than that after exposure without MPs, indicating an evident synergic impact of MPs with the petroleum hydrocarbons.
body_text.section: Impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination on the THC and cell type composition of hemocytes

body_text.text: Although the percentage of hyalinocytes in the hemocyte population was not affected, the percentage of red granulocytes was significantly reduced, whereas that of basophil granulocytes was significantly increased, upon exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and/or MPs (Table 2, F5,36 = 307.39 and 203.69 , p = 8.14E-25 and 3.33E-22 for that of red and basophil granulocytes, respectively). Similar to the results for the THC, the impacts of petroleum hydrocarbons on the percentages of red and basophil granulocytes might be dose dependent as well. In addition, the reduction in the proportion of red granulocytes and the increase in the proportion of basophil granulocytes caused by 100 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons were further aggravated with the copresence of MPs.
body_text.section: Impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination on the THC and cell type composition of hemocytes

body_text.text: Compared to that of the control, exposure to the tested pollutants alone or in combination for days led to a significant decline in the phagocytic activity of hemocytes (Figure 1, F5 ,36 = 148.30, p = 3.27E-20), indicating significant immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs to the blood clam. Furthermore, the toxic impact of petroleum hydrocarbons on phagocytosis not only may occur in a dose-dependent manner but was also aggravated by the copresence of MPs. For instance, the phagocytic activity of hemocytes from clams coexposed to or 100 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons with MPs were approximately 81.48% and 64.40% of that observed in clams treated with corresponding doses of petroleum hydrocarbons alone.
body_text.section: Impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination on the phagocytic activity of hemocytes

body_text.text: Compared to that of the control, the intracellular ROS content was significantly induced by the exposure of clams to petroleum hydrocarbons alone or in combination with MPs (Figure 2, F5 ,36 = 40.56, p = 1.83E-12). In addition, the results showed that the ability of petroleum hydrocarbons to induce the intracellular ROS content increased with the doses tested, suggesting a potential dose-dependent toxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons on intracellular ROS. Although no difference was detected between groups exposed to the low dose of petroleum hydrocarbons with and without MPs, the high dose of petroleum hydrocarbons combined with MPs dramatically aggravated the induction of the intracellular ROS content, which significantly increased by approximately 24%.
body_text.section: Impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination on the intracellular ROS content of hemocytes

body_text.text: Exposure of blood clams to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination for 14 days resulted in a significant decline in cell viability of hemocytes compared to that of control (Figure 3, F5 ,36 = 43.76, p = 6.81E-13). Similar to the hematic indexes and intracellular ROS content, the toxic impact of petroleum hydrocarbons on hemocyte viability may occur in a dose-dependent manner, as indicated by the significantly reduced cell viability (approximately 39.41%) in clams treated with a high dose of petroleum hydrocarbons compared with those treated with the lower dose. A significant elevation (aggravated by approximately 42.13%) in the toxic effect on cell viability caused by the copresence of MPs was also detected for blood clams exposed to the high dose of petroleum hydrocarbons.
body_text.section: Impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs on the cell viability of hemocytes

body_text.text: Though the degree of DNA damage of hemocytes was not affected by the MP treatment alone, it was significantly induced by exposing blood clams to petroleum hydrocarbons in a potential dose-dependent manner compared to the control, regardless of whether MPs were included (Figure 4, F5 ,18 = 335.73, p = 1.86E-12).
body_text.section: Impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs on the DNA damage of hemocytes

body_text.text: Compared to those exposed to 100 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons alone, hemocytes from clams coexposed to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs showed a significantly higher degree of DNA damage (approximately 1.36 times), indicating aggravated toxicity with the copresence of MPs.
body_text.section: Impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs on the DNA damage of hemocytes

body_text.text: The expression levels of NFκB1 and TAB2 from the immune-related NFκB signaling pathway were significantly suppressed by petroleum hydrocarbons ( Figure   5A , p < 0.05). In addition, the suppression of NFκB1 and TAB2 by a high dose of petroleum hydrocarbons was further aggravated by the copresence of MPs ( Figure 5A , p < 0.05). It was also found that the expression of NFκB1 was downregulated, whereas that of TAB2 was not affected by exposure of clams to MPs alone ( Figure   5A ). Although not affected by exposure to MPs and the low dose of petroleum hydrocarbons alone, coexposure to the low dose of petroleum hydrocarbons along with MPs and the high dose of petroleum hydrocarbons led to significant induction of AHR and ARNT expression ( Figure 5B , p < 0.05). However, compared to clams exposed to 100 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons alone, clams exposed to this level of petroleum hydrocarbons along with MPs showed significantly downregulated expression of AHR and ARNT ( Figure 5B ). Except for the high dose of petroleum hydrocarbons along with MPs, the expression levels of BAX and Caspase-3 from the apoptosis pathway were significantly induced by the two pollutants both alone or in combination ( Figure 5C, p < 0.05) . In addition, similar to the results of AHR and ARNT, the copresence of MPs resulted in the significant downregulation of BAX and Caspase-3 in clams exposed to the high dose of petroleum hydrocarbons ( Figure 5C ).
body_text.section: Impacts of exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs on the expression levels of the tested genes

body_text.text: Though sessile filter-feeding marine bivalves such as the blood clam may be exposed to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs simultaneously in realistic scenarios, to date, the immunotoxic impacts of these two types of pollutants and the underlying physiological and molecular toxication mechanisms still remain largely unknown in bivalve species. The present study showed that exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs alone or in combination at environmentally realistic concentrations could exert significant immunotoxic impacts on the blood clam, which may render blood clam more susceptible to environmental challenges; therefore, such pollution poses a severe threat to this species. In addition, the results obtained in this study demonstrated that the immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons could be significantly aggravated by the copresence of MPs, indicating that coexposure to petroleum components and MPs could be more hazardous and therefore deserve closer attention.

Phagocytosis by hemocytes is a key immune response of bivalve mollusks against pathogen infection (Loker et al., 2004; Allam and Raftos, 2015) . However, the data obtained in this study showed that exposure to the investigated pollutants significantly constrained phagocytosis in the blood clam. Based on the results of this study, inhibition of phagocytosis upon exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs may result from alterations in a series of physiological and molecular processes. First, exposure to both petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs led to a significant decline in the THC, indicating that a lower number of hemocytes is available for phagocytosis under the challenge of these two pollutants. Since red granulocytes have the highest phagocytic activity among the three types of hemocytes (Liu et al., 2016) , inhibited phagocytosis may be attributed to the reduction in the proportion of red granulocytes in the hemocyte population. In addition, the membrane and cytoskeleton of hemocytes, which are sensitive to intracellular ROS, play an essential role in the recognition and engulfment of foreign substances during the process of phagocytosis (Su et al., 2018) .

Since the intracellular ROS content in hemocytes was significantly induced by the tested pollutants, phagocytosis could also be constrained by the overproduction of ROS, which may damage the membrane and cytoskeleton of hemocytes and thus disrupt the efficient recognition and engulfment of foreign particles by hemocytes (Faggio et al., 2016; Capillo et al., 2018; Katsumiti et al., 2019; Freitas et al., 2020; Stara et al., 2020; Tang et al., 2020) . Similar to the membrane and cytoskeleton, DNA is also sensitive to oxidative stressors such as ROS (Cai et al., 2016; Parolini et al., 2016; Sahlmann et al., 2017) . Therefore, the aggravated DNA damage detected in this study may be caused by the overproduction of intracellular ROS. Since DNA integrity is essential to maintaining the normal function of the cell (Han et al., 2019), aggravated DNA damage induced by the tested pollutants may result in the reduced cell viability and inhibited phagocytosis. Finally, immune responses including phagocytosis are modulated by molecular pathways such as the NFκB signaling pathway (Tripathi and Aggarwal, 2006; Chen et al., 2016; Ren et al., 2017) . It is also well known that activation of AHR and ARNT could result in immunotoxic impacts such as constrained phagocytosis, regardless of whether it occurs by disrupting endocrine regulation or by interfering with immune-related molecular pathways (Gargaro et al., 2016; Neavin et al., 2018) . The data from this study showed that exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs generally downregulated the expression of NFκB1 and TAB2 from the NFκB signaling pathway but upregulated the expression of AHR and ARNT from the AHR immunotoxicity pathway. Therefore, disruption of these molecular pathways by the investigated pollutants offers another explanation for the inhibition of phagocytosis.

In this study, exposure to petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs led to a reduction in the THC and alteration in the cell type composition of hemocytes, which may be due to the following reasons. First, exposure to both MPs and petroleum may result in tissue damage in bivalve mollusks (Marigómez et al., 2006; von Moos et al., 2012; Sureda et al., 2013; Détrée and Gallardo-Escárate, 2018) . In this case, a proportion of hemocytes may be recruited to the damaged tissue, thereby decreasing the THC in the circulatory system (Liu et al., 2009) . Second, alterations in the THC and cell type composition may also be caused by disrupted hematopoiesis and apoptosis.

Overproduction of ROS can trigger the process of apoptosis by activating the apoptosis pathway (Hussain et al., 2010; Li et al., 2017) . In this study, the intracellular ROS content as well as the expression levels of the positive regulator BAX and the executor caspase-3 from the apoptosis pathway were generally increased by the tested pollutants, indicating that apoptosis was activated under pollutant challenge. In addition to modulating phagocytosis, NFκB plays an important role in hematopoiesis as a transcript factor to trigger proliferation (Gonzalez-Murillo et al., 2015) . Since the expression of NFκB was found to be significantly suppressed by both petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs, the normal process of hematopoiesis may be disrupted by these two pollutants as well.

Although the results of the present study offer a potential explanation for the immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs, these two pollutants may also exert immunotoxic impacts via affecting other physiological processes such as metabolism, energy supply, and neural-endocrine-immune regulation. For instance, a recent transcriptomic analysis demonstrated that exposure of blood clam to MPs led to alterations in metabolism processes such as those of lipids (Shi et al., 2020) . Since metabolism processes are closely related to immune regulation via cross-linked molecular pathways (Im et al., 2011; Han et al., 2018) , metabolic disorder could be another cause for the impairment of immune responses detected. In addition, both immune responses and hematopoiesis are energy-consuming processes (Turvey and Broide, 2010) . However, it has been suggested that the energy availability (indicated by ATP content in hemocytes) can be significantly reduced by exposure of bivalves to pollutants such as MPs (Shi et al., 2020) , which may thereby put a constraint on normal hematopoiesis and immune functions. Furthermore, significant alterations in the in vivo contents of hormones and neurotransmitters such as cortisol, acetylcholine (ACh), and γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) were also reported in bivalve species upon exposure to pollutants such as MPs (Guan et al., 2018; Shi et al., 2020) , indicating a disruption of neural-endocrine-immune regulation. Since the regulation of immune responses is extremely complicated, comprehensive toxication mechanisms underpinning the immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs await further in-deep investigations.

In this study, it was also demonstrated that the toxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons can be significantly aggravated by the copresence of MPs, which is comparable to those reported for other pollutants (González-Soto et al., 2019; Tang et al., 2020; Shi et al., 2020) . For instance, the immunotoxicity of 17b-estradiol and benzo[a]pyrene indicated by alterations in the THC, cell type composition, and phagocytic activity of hemocytes, were found to be significantly aggravated by the copresence of 1 mg/L PS MPs with a diameter of 500 nm (Tang et al., 2020) . This synergic effect exerted by MPs on the toxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons may be due to the Trojan horse effect and add-on effect. First, petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs both present a hydrophobic characteristic; thus, these hydrocarbons could be adsorbed on the surface of MPs, which may facilitate the internalization of petroleum hydrocarbons into the clam (Bakir et al., 2014a; Avio et al., 2015; Pittura et al., 2018) . Since the immunotoxicity of many pollutants is dose dependent, greater amount of petroleum hydrocarbons may enter and accumulated in the clam through this Trojan horse effect with the copresence of MPs and therefore result in the aggravation of immunotoxicity (Bakir et al., 2014b; Avio et al., 2015; Binelli et al., 2017) . In addition, since both petroleum hydrocarbons and MPs are immunotoxic to blood clams, the aggravation in toxicity may be simply caused by an add-on effect. It has been suggested that MPs smaller than 20 µm may enter the circulatory system of bivalve species and therefore be more toxic than their larger sized counterparts (Browne et al., 2008; Van Cauwenberghe and Janssen, 2014) . In addition, smaller MPs with relatively larger surface-to-volume ratio may carry more pollutants into the body of bivalve and thus exert more toxic impacts through the Trojan horse effect (Tang et al., 2020; Shi et al., 2020) . Therefore, the results obtained in this study indicate that MPs with smaller sizes could be immunotoxic to blood clam and may also aggravate the immunotoxicity of petroleum hydrocarbons.

Compared to clams exposed to 100 μg/L petroleum hydrocarbons alone, significant downregulation of AHR, ARNT, BAX, and caspase-3 was detected in the corresponding coexposure group, which may be related to negative feedback regulation to avoid further damage under severe pollutant challenge. For instance, the induction of AHR and ARNT will not only result in immunotoxic impacts but also activate cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzyme, which plays an important role in catalyzing the oxidative biotransformation and metabolism of xenobiotics such as PAHs and insecticides (Yim et al., 2017; Lee et al., 2018) . Though the activation of the AHR-CYP pathway helps to remove toxicants, some intermediate metabolites could be even more toxic to organisms (Shimada, 2006; Han et al., 2015; O'Driscoll et al., 2018) . To avoid further acute damage, negative feedback regulation could be triggered via the suppression of AHR by an AHR repressor (AHRR) or the export or degradation of AHR by specific ligands (Stevens et al., 2009; Zhou et al., 2010; Vogel and Haarmann-Stemmann, 2017) . Similarly, the downregulation of BAX and caspase-3 could also represent negative feedback regulation to avoid excessive apoptosis (Tang et al., 2020) .
